factoid: Emperor Alexander was still at Vílna when the forces were divided into three armies.
The first army was under Barclay de Tolly.
The second army was under Bagratión.
The third army was commanded by Tormásov.
Emperor Alexander was with the first army.
Emperor Alexander was not the commander in chief of the first army.
Orders issued stated that Emperor Alexander would not take command but would be with the army.
Emperor Alexander had with him the imperial headquarters staff, not a commander in chief’s staff.
Quartermaster General Prince Volkónski, the head of the imperial staff, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander.
Generals were in attendance on Emperor Alexander.
Imperial aides-de-camp were in attendance on Emperor Alexander.
Diplomatic officials were in attendance on Emperor Alexander.
A large number of foreigners were in attendance on Emperor Alexander.
The army staff was not in attendance on Emperor Alexander.
Arakchéev, the ex‑Minister of War, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Count Bennigsen, the senior general in rank, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Grand Duke Tsarévich Constantine Pávlovich was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Count Rumyántsev, the Chancellor, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Stein, a former Prussian minister, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Armfeldt, a Swedish general, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Pfuel, the chief author of the plan of campaign, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Paulucci, an adjutant general and Sardinian émigré, was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
Wolzogen was in attendance on Emperor Alexander without a definite appointment.
The presence of Emperor Alexander and these people meant that Emperor Alexander did not assume the title of commander in chief but disposed of all the armies.
The men around Emperor Alexander were his assistants.
Arakchéev was a faithful custodian who enforced order and acted as Emperor Alexander’s bodyguard.
Bennigsen was a landlord in the Vílna province who appeared to be doing the honors of the district.
Bennigsen was in reality a good general, useful as an adviser and ready at hand to replace Barclay.
Grand Duke Tsarévich Constantine Pávlovich was there because it suited him to be.
Stein was there because his advice was useful and Emperor Alexander held him in high esteem personally.
Armfeldt virulently hated Napoleon and was a general full of self‑confidence.
Armfeldt’s self‑confidence always influenced Emperor Alexander.
Paulucci was there because he was bold and decided in speech.
The adjutant generals were there because they always accompanied Emperor Alexander.

Pfuel was there because he had drawn up the plan of campaign against Napoleon and, having induced Emperor Alexander to believe in the efficacy of that plan, was directing the whole business of the war.
With Pfuel was Wolzogen, who expressed Pfuel’s thoughts in a more comprehensible way than Pfuel himself.
Pfuel was a harsh, bookish theorist, self‑confident to the point of despising everyone else.
The foreigners propounded new and unexpected ideas every day, especially the foreigners, who did so with a boldness characteristic of people employed in a country not their own.
Many secondary personages accompanied the army because their principals were there.
Prince Andrew noticed sharply defined subdivisions of tendencies and parties.
The first party consisted of Pfuel and his adherents, military theorists who believed in a science of war with immutable laws.
The first party believed in laws of oblique movements, outflankings, and so forth.
Pfuel and his adherents demanded a retirement into the depths of the country in accordance with precise laws defined by a pseudo‑theory of war.
Pfuel and his adherents saw only barbarism, ignorance, or evil intention in every deviation from that theory.
The first party included foreign nobles, Wolzogen, Wintzingerode, and others, chiefly Germans.
